title: blob:
content:
Hello,

I process phishing URL's,

I have recently come across URL's that make use of a BLOB: syntax on the URL:

blob:https://bolig.botik.dk/16c8c011-0fa5-4ba0-a10f-ed7675055cc6

You can see an example of the Phishing URL in this PhishTank entry:

https://phishtank.com/phish_detail.php?phish_id=9118779

That URL then re-directs to the above "BLOB" URL.

My understanding is that it is "locally" generating the phishing website, similar to an old fashioned about: syntax, however it's not clear what the significance of bolig.botik.dk URL is - loading that URL without the BLOB: prefix causes an error

Can someone explain:

1) What is the BLOB: syntax, and 2) what would be reported to have the phishing URL removed in the above example?
creator: justin1987au2

title: Key4.db file is missing in the folder I copied over from old PC
content:
Hello,

as the title suggests, I moved my whole profile folder to a new PC, and have since formated my old PC. I just noticed that the key4.db file is missing from the old profile folder. I have followed all instructions I managed to google, which ensured that it was enough to just copy over the old folder content into the new one, nowhere was it mentioned to look after if a key4 or key3 file are present. How is it possible that multiple of your support articles don't mention this? I am now stuck with only a json.login file from my old profile and no way to import my saved logins to the new PC.

title: Access Limitation to Specific Site
content:
Full access to one of my favorite websites -- BillO'Reilly.com, which I visit daily -- has been compromised through Firefox. If I access it's home page, it briefly appears in color -- then quickly changes to black and white! This is the case in pages throughout the site. Only O'Reilly's "No Spin News" program comes in color but, only if you're a paid subscriber to the site. The site comes in perfectly on other browsers (e.g. Chrome and Edge) and I have informed the site's technical staff about the issue.

Please look into this.

--Thanks, Steve Saucedo 

  Firefox User Since Its Beginning
creator: slsaucedo3

title: file:///d:/web/index.html not valid URL
content:
If I enter file:///d:/web/index.html in the search box then it returns the expected web page but if I edit it into a Firefox home page shortcut then I'm told a valid URL is required. A bit of research here makes me think I need to edit policies.json but I can't find that file in Windows 10, Firefox 139.0.1. I note that the posts giving the advice are six years old and Firefox has changed greatly since then. Please could someone tell me the current method to achieve what I want?

Jonathan
